utterances: What do you mean the last royal couple?
You're talking about abolishing the monarchy here?
Well, I think, you know, by the time - it really depends on the next sort of 20 years.
I mean, I think that if William and Kate could come in faster, it'll be way better for the monarchy.
But Charles is not going to abdicate in any way.
He has waited for this for so long.
And he's also, I am told, really determined that Camilla will be queen.
It's very interesting.
The nation does not want Camilla to be queen.
They don't dislike her but they don't want her to be queen.
They would like to skip to William and Kate.
It's not going to happen.
I mean, that requires a whole constitutional reorganization and it would require Prince Charles to really want to make himself scarce, and he does not want to do that.
Meaning that there's going to be resistance here but you think it's going to happen.
I mean, the crown is going to be passed on here.

The crown will be passed on to Charles and the great question is, is how patient the British people are going to be when he's king and the expense and the lack of popularity of Charles, you know, meet a head-on collision.
So Will and Kate here have got perhaps decades, certainly many years, before they're ever going to be king and queen.
What are they supposed to do for that time and what does the public expect of them?
Well, Kate, primarily, has to do one thing, which is breed, produce a whole bunch of heirs.
An heir and a spare and maybe a couple more.
So she's going to be very focused, I think, on trying to have kids and doing charity work.
William, of course, is still in the air force.
He wants to, I think, very much continue with his life in that area.

And you know, I think that they're just going to try to lead a life that's worthy, that's increasing in its charitable, you know, presence, and show that they are people who care as much as anything else, because that's really a very important thing for the monarchy right now, to show it cares.
In that sense, that is Diana's legacy.
Tina Brown of The Daily Beast and Newsweek.
Always a pleasure to speak with you.
Thank you.
And she's also the author of ""The Diana Chronicles.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Audie Cornish.
In Spain, where the economic crisis has ravaged society, public protest has become a way of life.
A year and a half ago, it was Indignados - or angry ones - who filled the streets.
The mass protests inspired the worldwide Occupy Movement.
Now the protests have evolved to encompass all of society, from victims of foreclosures to the entire judiciary.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli reports from Madrid on this new form of anti-austerity resistance.
Hardly a day passes without a noisy demonstration by one sector of society or another.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC AND PROTESTERS)
Today, it's doctors.

Olwen Leaman, a young oncologist at the Princesa Hospital, is one of the thousands of white-clad health workers protesting government plans to overhaul the country's highly-respected public health system.
DR. OLWEN LEAMAN: What they want to do is privatize the hospital and we are here to just to say we don't want that to happen.
We want that to stop because we think that it has to be universal; that everybody has to be able to go to hospital.
The next day, it's university professors and students.
(Foreign language spoken)
In a central square, a political science professor lectures on Hobbes and the nature of power to note-taking students sitting on the pavement.
The mere idea of legalizing pot has always been known as a third rail in politics, but now it appears to be gaining a tiny bit of traction, according to recent polls.
Currently, 13 states have medical marijuana laws, and the Obama administration has signaled a more lenient attitude towards dispensaries in those states.
And even conservative pundit Glenn Beck of Fox News has joined the debate on legalization.
Look, I'm a libertarian.
You want to legalize marijuana, you want to legalize drugs, that's fine.
We have to have a different conversation in America.
But President Obama has made it clear he doesn't support legalizing pot, and Ammiano is the first to say he doesn't expect to win this battle anytime soon.
Polls are looking good.
So you know, I just want to be very strategic about this, not put anyone on the spot.
But his effort begs the question, is a first-time lawmaker from notoriously liberal San Francisco the right soldier to champion the legalization of pot?
Mr.
A.G.
BLOCK (Associate Director, University of California Center Sacramento): Well, it's not Nixon going to China.
A.G.
Block is the associate director of UC Center, Sacramento.
Would it be better if, you know, some conservative Republican from Riverside County was carrying this?
Oh yeah, sure.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That would be better because you break down some of the stereotypical opposition to it.
But Ammiano's supporters say that beyond his self-deprecating wit, there is a hard-nosed politico who knows how to get deals done.

He not only championed liberal causes such as domestic partner and universal health care laws, but also middle of the road budget issues such as insisting that San Francisco keep a rainy day reserve fund for economic bad times like now.
But legalizing pot could be a legislative brick wall.
Ammiano says many conservative lawmakers in Sacramento have told him privately that they think it's a good idea but aren't ready yet to go public.
And when asked how he'll win over their support, Ammiano replies, don't underestimate me.
Richard Gonzales, NPR News.
On Monday's our business report focuses on technology.
Today, AT&T stakes its claim on the wireless industry.
AT&T is buying BellSouth in a stock deal valued at $67 billion.
The two companies already jointly own Cingular and now AT&T will own all of that wireless company.
But remember, this is not the AT&T of old.
The company would have gone out of business if it weren't for another Baby Bell called SBC, which bought AT&T late last year and took over its name.
And this just announced purchase of BellSouth is the latest in a string of takeovers by chairman Ed Whitacre.
USA Today telecommunications reporter Leslie Cauley joins me now to discuss the deal and the CEO behind it.
Good morning.
Good morning.
So what is Ed Whitacre's strategy in this purchase?

Ed Whitacre's strategy for, he was appointed CEO and chairman in 1990, and really since then he has been on a single-minded effort, on his part, to re-aggregate in some manor a vestige of the old Bell system.
He likes, fundamentally, the big bundle, one stop shopping.
He grew up in that era of the old Bell system.
He's a 40-year-plus veteran of the old Bell system, remembers it fondly.
And he likes the AT&T name, he likes the idea, again, of offering all these services the old Ma Bell offered to the public, and he is now able to do that today as a result of this deal.
And as I've just said, this is not the old AT&T, although it's certainly starting to look like it.
It certainly is.
Ed has, with the BellSouth deal, Ed will bring into the fold, his company's fold, four out of the original seven regional phone companies.
The other two belong to Verizon, and one stand-alone, Qwest, has the old US West asset.
And the only standalone company at this point is Qwest, which is an amalgam on the old U.S.
West asset.
So he has four out of seven.
And interestingly, when he was appointed CEO and chairman in 1990, he sat atop the smallest, the puniest, if you will, of the regional Bell, Southwestern Bell.
And over a period of time, due to deal making, it is now the largest one in the country.
Ed Whitacre just completed the acquisition of AT&T last November.
How was he able to turn around so quickly and then buy BellSouth?
Is part of his modus operandi to move fast?
It is.
And also, it speaks to the way SPC under Ed Whitacre functions.
He has a board that has a lot of confidence in him, gives him a lot of reign, a lot of latitude to do these deals.
'Cause you're quite correct, that's in stark contrast to a company like BellSouth, which completely sat out the merger dance of the 1990s.
BellSouth has a disposition to study things exhaustively and even as it studies the market changes and consequently this company has never done a major transaction.
BellSouth did come close to buying AT&T and backed out, and at that time SBC, Ed Whitacre once more swooped in and bought the prize.
And so this, again, it speaks to a lot of different factors.
Culturally, SBC under Ed Whitacre, he's been there as CEO and chairman for like 15 years now.
They give him a wide reign and latitude to do what he does.
The deal of course has to be approved by regulators.
Just briefly, will they approve this deal?
Chances are good that yes, they will.
It will have to go through state regulatory review as well as federal.
But again, every Bell merger, starting in the early mid-90s, has been approved.
There's no reason to believe this one won't.
Although it could, because it's one of the last standing big credible Bells left, there will be a lot of conversation, discussion, no question.
USA Today reporter Leslie Cauley is the author of End of the Line: The Rise and Fall of AT&T.
Thank you.
You're most welcome.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
